results.title: The Genie from down under: customs
results.creator_credit: Jeremy Swan, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones, ABC-TV (Australia), Australian Children's Television Foundation and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Penelope, Lady Diana and Miss Mossop are arrested by a Customs Officer when they return to England with 20 million pounds provided by the genies. That exact amount has just gone missing from the Royal Mint.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jeremy Swan, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones, ABC-TV (Australia), Australian Children’s Television Foundation and British Broadcasting Corporation

results.title: The Genie from down under: larceny
results.creator_credit: Brendan Maher, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones, ABC-TV (Australia), Australian Children's Television Foundation and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Bruce helps Otto and Conrad get the opal because he thinks they will help him return to Australia. Instead, the von Meisters sell it for 25,000 pounds. It’s now up to the genies to sort the mess out.

results.title: The Genie from down under: wishing and hoping
results.creator_credit: Esben Storm, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones, ABC-TV (Australia), Australian Children's Television Foundation and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: When upper class English girl Penelope Townes finds a magic opal which contains two Australian genies, Bruce and his son Baz, she thinks all her problems are over, and that she can have anything she wants. Bruce, however, has other ideas.

results.title: The Genie from down under: where it's at
results.creator_credit: Esben Storm, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones, ABC-TV (Australia), Australian Children's Television Foundation and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Bruce wants to become human but to do this he must take the opal to the cave where it was mined over a hundred years before. He sets out to trick Penelope into visiting the cave.

results.title: The Genie from down under: it's my opal and I'll cry if I want to
results.creator_credit: Jeremy Swan, Patricia Edgar, Phil Jones, ABC-TV (Australia), Australian Children's Television Foundation and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Tour operator, Otto von Meister, and his nephew, Conrad, arrive at Townes Downs with a load of tourists. When he learns about the opal Otto recalls that it belonged to their family years before and he and Conrad are desperate to get it back.

results.title: Marco Solo
results.creator_credit: Adrian Bosich and VCA Film and Television School, University of Melbourne
results.brief_description:
Poor Marco. Accidentally born into an overcrowded Australian-Italian household, he is relegated to his parents’ bedroom. Nine years later, armed with a vivid imagination, an obsession with Dame Edna, and a warped sense of Catholicism, Marco searches for a space of his own. Cast includes Joseph Sollena, Robert Urban, Helen Nicholas, Irini Pappas, Maria Diele.
‘Marco Solo’ screened at many film festivals, including Palm Springs and London International Film Festival.

results.title: Blue Tongue
results.creator_credit: Justin Kurzel, Timothy Jolley and VCA Film and Television School, University of Melbourne
results.brief_description:
On the fringes of a housing estate a girl seduces a boy with a secret she will only reveal in exchange for his love. When the boy fails to honour the pact, what he holds close is threatened by the girl’s desire for revenge. Cast: Arlan Fahey Leigh and Siana Smit.
In 2005 ‘Blue Tongue’ was the first Australian short film to be selected for screening at the International Critics Week at the Cannes International Film Festival.

results.brief_description: 1. New kinds of scratch imagery reflect the disparate element of the title as dots and dashes squiggle about the screen. Supported by a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts. (A Federal Agency, Washington DC)

results.title: Tal Farlow
results.brief_description: Jazz guitarist Tal Farlow provides the background music to Lye’s final film, which, although begun in the 1950s, was not recommenced until the 1980s. Unfortunately he died before completing it. It contains vertical white scratches as well as geometric white scratches on black. It was completed by Lye’s assistant Steve Jones under the supervision of Ann Lye. Supported in part by a grant from the Queen Elizabeth II Arts Council of New Zealand.
